question: What kind of clouds are likely to appear just before the snow starts?

content.source_1: The local forecast calls for a heavy snowstorm later today, indicating an approaching midlatitude cyclone.
content.source_2: Ahead of an approaching midlatitude cyclone, surface barometric pressure typically falls steadily, often right up to the onset of precipitation.
content.source_3: After the low-pressure center passes a location, surface pressure bottoms out and begins to rise, even though precipitation can continue or redevelop.
content.source_4: Many major winter storms produce their most intense “wraparound” or deformation-band snow on the backside of the low, which often arrives after the pressure minimum, during the rising-pressure phase.
content.source_5: Snow commonly occurs with near-freezing surface temperatures; small temperature fluctuations around 0°C do not uniquely indicate whether pressure is falling or rising.
content.source_6: Thickening stratiform clouds and gusty winds are common both before and after a low’s passage, so these signs alone do not determine whether pressure is falling or rising.
